title: What will happen to our house and other assets?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: During the divorce process, your home and other assets will most likely be divided. The approach will be guided by local and state laws, usually with the goal of creating fairness for all parties. Your division of assets might be based on a variety of factors, like the value of your property, history, lifestyle, infidelity, the needs of any children involved, or the earning potential of either individual.

title: How much does a divorce cost?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: The cost of your divorce will depend on your unique circumstances, including the assets that must be divided, any children who must be accommodated, and how contentious the situation is between you and your spouse. Simple, uncontested cases can be as little as a few hundred dollars, while complex, drawn-out cases can run much higher, with some couples spending more than $100,000 to dissolve their marriage.

title: How do I tell my kids about divorce?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: Talking to your children about a divorce can be difficult. They often won’t understand what’s happening or why. Explain to them that they are loved and that it’s not their fault. Be honest about how things will have to adjust due to temporary and long-term custody arrangements, but try not to scare them by overwhelming them with sudden life changes. Give them time to be sad or angry, but also make sure you leave the lines of communication open in case they want to express themselves.

title: How do you tell your friends and family that you are getting divorced?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: When you are ready to share your news, start by reaching out to trusted friends or family directly. Avoid posting divorce-related content on social media. If there are children involved, approach them with honesty and compassion.

meta.article_link: a:3:{s:5:"title";s:54:"How to Tell Your Friends that You Are Getting Divorced";s:3:"url";s:94:"https://www.divorcelawyer.com/articles/how-to-tell-your-friends-that-you-are-getting-divorced/";s:6:"target";s:0:"";}

title: How long does divorce typically take?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: The divorce process can take as few as 31 days in most states, but it normally takes six to twelve months. If there are major differences that need to be worked out, be prepared for the process to take more than a year. The timeline can widely vary based on your circumstances, location, state laws, what is being contested, and how you and your spouse choose to handle the negotiations and proceedings. Consult an attorney for guidance on your unique circumstances.

title: How much alimony will I get?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: Depending on your state, alimony is not necessarily required, but it can be awarded to either party if it is justified by financial circumstances. Alimony is separate from child support, may influenced by a prenuptial agreement, and is mostly included in situations that involve lengthy marriages, when one spouse doesn’t work, or a condition that prevents a spouse from supporting themselves. Alimony is not considered a broad remedy, but a support system if needed.

title: Do I need to go to court?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: In many cases, you do not need to go to court and can resolve issues through negotiation or mediation. If you and your spouse can agree on key decisions, such as asset division, alimony, and child custody, you may be able to settle the divorce and submit an agreement to the court for approval without litigation. If you are not able to reach an agreement, final decisions may need court intervention. A skilled divorce attorney can help you understand the best options for your situation.

title: How do I pick the right divorce lawyer?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: Choose an attorney who will provide legal expertise and offer the support and guidance you need to go forward with confidence. Research lawyers in your area and look for someone who specializes in divorce, understands your state laws, can skillfully navigate the complexities of your case, has experience that is similar to your unique circumstances, and fits within your budget. Compatibility and communication style are also important.

title: Do I need a reason to file for divorce?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: In most states, you do not need a specific reason to file for divorce. “No-fault” divorce laws allow you to file due to things like irreconcilable differences or an irretrievable breakdown of the marriage, without assigning blame to either spouse. Some states still allow for "fault-based" divorce, where one spouse cites specific grounds that may impact aspects of the divorce settlement. An experienced divorce attorney can help you determine how best to file.

title: What is the divorce process like?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: Each situation is unique, guided by state laws, and can be more or less complicated than you expect. The process may include filing for divorce, serving papers, response, discovery, and negotiations. If you can agree to the terms, your divorce might be finalized without litigation. In contentious cases where you can’t reach an agreement on key decisions, it may have to be litigated in court. A skilled attorney can assess your situation and help you know what to expect.

title: What are the different child custody options?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: Child custody will be based on your unique family circumstances, guided by state laws, and designed to best meet the needs of your children. Common options include standard, extended, weekly, 2/2/3, and variations of those custody arrangements. A skilled attorney can help tailor a plan to fit your needs.

title: What is DivorceLawyer.com?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: DivorceLawyer.com (DL) is the only website community dedicated to educating you about divorce and the divorce process. Top, vetted local law firms and attorneys work with us to grow this national content library, along with other professionals and people like you that have already gone through this emotional process.

title: What makes DivorceLawyer.com different from all those law firm directory sites?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: Law firm directory sites try to be everything to everybody, and you can see what happened. They list thousands of lawyers practicing all types of law in all areas of the country. DivorceLawyer.com was built specifically for you, providing the best educational information and direct access to top local attorneys.

title: How do you pick your law firm members?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: We only approach the best of the best, top law firms with attorneys who are leaders and role models in their communities, state Bar associations, and national organizations. We rely on peer recommendations, and also review quantitative data on experience, status, certifications, and reputation. If you ask around, you’ll hear these same names.

title: Who creates the content on your site?
creator: DivorceLawyer.com
excerpt: DivorceLawyer.com produces all content in partnership with our law firm members. Our goal is to educate by sharing real and unique experiences in a standard, easy-to-view format, so DL becomes your go-to resource for divorce information. Our law firm members also introduce us to industry professionals, as well as people like you who have gone through the divorce experience.

title: What do I do when I’m ready to contact a lawyer?
creator: sorcram@gmail.com
excerpt: The best thing about DivorceLawyer.com is that we’ve already found the top law firms and attorneys in your area. They contributed to our national content library, and are ready to help when needed. You can see the three top local law firms on almost every page. Just click on a firm to learn more, meet their featured attorneys, and schedule a consultation.
